Award.AwardTitle: Subcretion Versus Relamination: Testing Processes of Lower Crustal Modification in the Klamath Mountain Accretionary Province
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tectonic collision zones represent locations in which continental crust is formed and/or physically and chemically modified. It is therefore important to determine how large masses of rock (terranes) are added to or removed from the crust during collision events. It is also important to understand the thermal history of these environments in terms of timing, temperature extremes, sources of heat, and geologic consequences, including potential for economic mineral deposits. Traditional theories for terrane addition involves emplacement of cold oceanic terranes beneath existing continental rocks. However, recent theories suggest a process (relamination) in which hot, partially melted rocks are emplaced at the base of the crust. This research will test these theories in the Klamath Mountain geologic province (CA and OR), where the potential for ancient relamination is strong. The research will also develop best practices for future studies of relamination elsewhere and will develop a detailed thermal history of the Klamath province that can be used to better understand economic resources, regional geologic history, and landscape development. Lastly, because the economy of the area is becoming increasingly dependent on tourism, additional products designed to promote eco-tourism include field guides and web-based information resources for the general public.

Because relamination involves emplacement of hot metasedimentary rocks at the base of the crust, a number of distinctive geologic features should result, in particular: rapid heating and metamorphism of the overlying terranes and lower-crustal modification of arc magmas due to contamination by relaminated metasedimentary rocks in the lower crust. The research will tightly constrain the timing of deformation and high-grade metamorphism relative to magmatism through detailed field mapping and sampling. High-precision (CA-ID-TIMS) U-Pb ages on zircon and rutile from high-grade migmatites and key pinning plutons will provide age constraints of orogenic events. These ages will be combined with field and microstructural data and P-T estimates (mineral equilibria and pseudosections) to develop a complete Pressure-Temperature-time-Deformation (P-T-t-D) history. Regional sampling of plutons that span accretionary events in both time and space will yield zircons that will be analyzed for oxygen isotopes (SIMS) and dated and analyzed for Hf isotopes by LA-ICPMS to characterize temporal and spatial changes in magma sources and contaminants, and thereby the changes in the lower crustal architecture caused by relamination.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Evolution of continental margins often involves addition of oceanic rocks by processes of accretion. Such accretion may occur by a variety of mechanisms, such as collision, subduction (subcretion), and even rise of subducted rocks upward to add to the crust (relamination). Our project involved study of a suite of plutons and related high-temperature metamorphic rocks in the central Klamath Mountain province of California and Oregon. We applied a range of field and laboratory methods to learn if the high-temperature metamorphism, magmatic activity, and additions to the crust were the result of relamination or of some other processes. 

Dating of zircon crystals from rocks that were partly melted during the high-temperature event indicated that they were too young to be cause by relamination, and instead formed during subcretion, as, wet, cool, underlying rocks release water to overlying hot rocks, leading to melting. This discovery led to further dating of the mineral rutile, which supported our new results. 

Our additional problem was that our new dates disagreed with older age determinations. We therefore resampled and redated rutile from the old locality and learned that dating by newer methods also yielded younger ages. This combination of age information leads to the conclusion that and important addition of new crust to the North American margin occurred from 157 to about 150 million years ago: the so-called Nevadan orogeny. 

However, subcretion cannot explain how so many rocks were metamorphosed to high temperatures prior to Nevadan orogeny. So the second part of our project involved dating and isotopic analysis of zircon crystals from a range of plutons which intruded before, during, and after the metamorphic event. Although our results are not final due to Covid-related delays, we know that before and after high-temperature metamorphism, magmas had little interaction with the crust. However, during high-temperature metamorphism, magmas reacted extensively with the crust, as shown by oxygen and hafnium isotope ratios in the zircons. This interaction occurred very deep in the crust, well beneath the modern surface. Thus, we have used the zircons from plutons as a means of 'remote sensing' of the lower crust during a particular time in earth history.

Our results suggest that huge volumes of magma collected in the lower Klamath Mountain crust from about 169 to 156 million years ago. Heat from these magmas caused the high-temperature metamorphism. Then, subcretion of cold rocks during the Nevadan orogeny halted magmatism and refrigerated the metamorphic rocks.

Our work involved four faculty members at Texas Tech University (TTU) along with four PhD and two MS students. Much of our research was conducted in the field area and in TTU laboratories, but students also worked in or with laboratories at Princeton Univ., the Univ. of Wisconsin-Madison, and the Univ. of Oklahoma. Ancillary projects involved colleagues at the Univ. of Alabama and the Queensland University of Science and Technology.

Our results are being published in scientific journals and, in addition, will be used to develop geologic field guides for the area.
